decision_conditions: Approval: To carry out tree surgery, including a crown lift by 1m and a crown reduction by 1m to Two Oaks (T4 and T7 on application), to crown lift by 1m and prune the branches overhanging the extension to the Western Red Cedars (G5 on application), To remove epicormic growth to a height of 8m and crown thin by 15% One Oak (T9 on application) all within Area 1 on TPO 392
Refusal: To fell Two Western Red Cedar (G5 on application), to crown reduce by 1-3m Five Beech trees (G1, T2 and T3 on application), all within Area 1 on TPO 392

The Oak, Beech and Western Red Cedar trees form a boundary line between 15 and 13 Linksway. Along with other nearby trees this group helps to provide a gradual transition of mature tree cover between the dwellings in Linksway and the nearby Ruislip woods National Nature Reserve (NNR)

The trees contribute to local biodiversity, and significantly contribute to the amenity and arboreal / wooded character of the Copsewood Estate Area of Special Local Character. The trees as a group have a high amenity value.

With regard to the proposed felling of two Western Red Cedars (within G5 on application) the included Arboricultural report (GD/200002/sh) mentions current damage to the side extension, however they have ticked no to question 6.2 "alleged damage to property" and no evidence in relation to root analysis or level monitoring have been submitted to quantify this allegation. There is mention in the report of a recent Structural Engineer's Report however this has not been supplied. With rega

The tree(s) to be pruned shall be crown reduced as per the approved specification. This work shall comprise a reduction in both height and spread over the whole crown by shortening or removing peripheral branches in a uniform and systematic manner.  Where branches are shortened, they should be cut back to a suitably positioned secondary branch.

Crown reduction shall not be construed as 'lopping' or 'topping' and shall result in a tree of typical form for the species and of balanced appearance. The works shall be carried out in accordance with the recommendations contained in BS 3998:2010 'Tree work - Recommendations'. Climbing irons or 'spikes' shall not be used during the execution of the work.
REASON
In order to protect health of the tree and the visual amenity of the area.

The tree(s) to be pruned shall be crown thinned as per the approved specification.  This work shall comprise the removal of all dead, diseased, rubbing (if less than 25mm in diameter) and dangerous branches along with an amount of live, secondary branch growth, throughout the entire crown of the tree, up to the amount specified above.  Final pruning cuts shall be made at the branch collar and this shall be left intact.

The amount of crown thinning shall be expressed as a percentage of the entire crown.  The works shall be carried out in accordance with the recommendations contained in BS 3998:2010 'Tree work - Recommendations'. Climbing irons or 'spikes' shall not be used during the execution of this work.  The result of this work shall be a tree of well-balanced appearance.
REASON
In order to protect health of the tree and the visual amenity of the area.

The tree(s) to be pruned shall be crown lifted as per the approved specification. This work shall involve the tip reduction of low hanging branches and/or the removal of low branches to the height specified and result in a tree of balanced appearance; those branches to be removed shall be removed at their origin and all branch collars shall be left intact.

The works shall be carried out in accordance with the recommendations contained in BS 3998:2010 'Tree work - Recommendations'. Climbing irons or 'spikes' shall not be used during the execution of this work.
REASON
In order to protect health of the tree and the visual amenity of the area.
The removal of deadwood, dangerous / hanging branches and ivy:  This does not require the formal consent of the Council.

Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981:  Note that it is an offence under this act to disturb roosting bats, nesting birds or any other protected species.  Therefore, if applicable, it is advisable to consult your tree surgeon / consultant to agree an acceptable time for carrying out the approved works.
Owner(s)'s permission:  Permission should be sought from the owner(s) of the tree(s) and / or the owner(s) of the land that the tree(s) overhang prior to any approved work being carried out.
Refusal of part of the requested works: The applicant retains a right of appeal against the part of the application that has effectively been refused.

Expected standard of tree work: The approved works must be carried out in accordance with the conditions laid out above. If they are not, then enforcement action could being taken which could lead to prosecution and heavy fines. Therefore, it is highly recommended that the works are only carried out by a professional and competent arboriculturist who undertakes to comply with the conditions of this consent and in accordance with industry best practice (BS 3998:2010). The Arboricultural Association can provide details of its approved contractors, who have demonstrated such professionalism and competence, on their website (www.trees.org.uk) or by calling 01242 522152. Or on request the Council can provide a list of contractors who are known to carry out tree work to a good standard and to normally maintain an appropriate policy of indemnity insurance.
description: To carry out tree surgery, including a crown lift by 1m and a crown reduction by 1m to Two Oaks (T4 and T7 on application), to fell Two Western Red Cedar and crown lift by 1m and prune the branches overhanging the extension to the remaining Western Red Cedars (G5 on application), to crown reduce by 1-3m Five Beech trees (G1, T2 and T3 on application), To remove epicormic growth to a height of 8m and crown thin by 15% One Oak (T9 on application) all within Area 1 on TPO 392
